column8: Wear our Brian Clough t-shirt to admire the greatest manager England never had. Under Clough, Nottingham Forest won the English league championship, two consecutive European Cups and four League Cups, this achievement is considered to be one of the greatest in football history. He had an unrivalled ability to motivate players. A working class hero who was always outspoken, self-confident & controversial, Brian Clough is famous for his witty quotes and aphorisms. I have used some of his best quotes in my design, with my favourite being "I wouldn't say I was the best manager in the business, but I was in the top one." A legendary figure that England should have appointed as their National manager, admire and remember Cloughy with this t-shirt.
column21: Brian Clough had an unrivalled ability to motivate players. A working class hero who was always outspoken, self-confident & controversial, admire and remember him by wearing this t-shirt.

column5: Default Category/space & aviation,Default Category/Science & Nature,Default Category/History & Politics
column8:
This t-shirt admires the incredible adventure set-out & achieved by the Americans in the 1960's. The Apollo Program was such a great accomplishment, it was an amazing effort with so much achieved in such a short time.

In 1957 the Soviets launched Sputnik, and began the space race with the Americans, who, with various rocket failures and missed opportunities, was losing out. They were second at almost everything - 2nd to launch an object into orbit, 2nd to launch a man into space, 2nd to perform an EVA (spacewalk) etc. etc. Something needed to be done and fast. President Kennedy wanted to know what they could do, and do it first, before the Soviets. They needed something bold that would let the world know they were technologically on par, or better still, ahead of the Soviets. Kennedy's advisors suggested focusing their efforts to landing a man on the moon, So that is what he decided to work towards... you can't get much bolder than that!

I'm not sure if Kennedy ever realised the enormity of his request he gave to his country, "to land a man on the moon and return him safely to the Earth" (within 10 years!). It happened though, and the immense effort put into achieving that goal was unbelievable. 400,000 people, new technologies designed and training by the astronauts that would make most science fiction stories seem boring.

This particular design focuses on the amazing fact that less than 100 years before they landed on the moon, aircraft hadn't even been invented, even cars were a novelty and the thought of landing men on the moon was absolutely ludicrous. I have used a quote from one of my favourite astronauts, Charlie Duke (of Apollo 16) said that his father "was born shortly after the Wright Brothers" and he went on to say that his father could hardly believe what his son was doing and never really got his head around it. Wear this t-shirt to admire how far we have come in such a short time...

Chess is believed to have originated in India in the 6th Century at this point it was a much earlier form of the game we now play. From there it moved to Persia, and through Persian and Muslim trading it was brought to Europe and spread throughout by the turn of the millenia.
It has undergone many changes since then, the last big changes being made around 1500.
Today it is still as strong as ever, and this design showing relics of the game from all over the world for the last thousand years, is a testament to it's age old popularity.
column21: Chess t shirt. This can be found under our arts and culture category. Originated in India in the 6th century

column8: Said to be Britains favourite dish. It also sits at the heart of argument between Scotland and India, as both claim the dish to have originated in their countries. There are many different recipes for this dish. I just included the main ingredients.
column21: A t-shirt celebrating the nation's favourite meal, Chicken Tikka. But is it Inidian or Scottish? If you ask us, the name doesn't sound very Scottish... From weadmire.net
